value: This League Went Into Effect On July 1, 2013, And Is Comprised Of Former Big East Conference Member Universities (university Of Cincinnati; University Of Connecticut; University Of Louisville; Rutgers, The State University Of New Jersey; Temple University; And University Of South Florida), And Former Conference Usa Member Universities (university Of Central Florida University Of Houston, University Of Memphis, And Southern Methodist University).

100% Privately Financed. Funds Were Being Privately Raised In Hopes Of Building A New Stadium. James N. Gamble, Of Procter And Gamble, Provided The Funds Needed To Complete The Horseshoe Shaped Stadium.

In December 2012, The University Of Cincinnati Announced Plans To Update And Expand Nippert Stadium. Renovations Are Expected To Cost Around $70 Million With The Main Focus On Adding More Seating And Suites. The Goal Is To Increase Capacity To Over 40,000. The Project Is Projected To Cost Between $60â€“70 Million And Utilize Private Donations, Not Public Funds.
The Stadium Was Named After Gambleâ€™s Grandson, James Gamble Nippert. Nippert Was A Uc Football Player Who Was Injured During A 1923 Game And Died As A Result Of His Injuries.
$91.2 Million Percentage Of Stadium Publicly Financed
Column: The State of Connecticut contributed an unspecified percentage of funds and has invested more than $92 million in the stadium to attract the best events and concerts to the state.

value: The Facility Is The Result Of Teamwork And Dedication Between The Stateâ€™s Office Of Policy And Management, The Town Of East Hartford, United Technologies Corporation, And The Assistance Of Numerous Public And Private Sector Organizations. The State Of Connecticut Owns The Stadium.

In October 2012, The Capital Regional Development Authority Announced They Were Seeking Proposals For Both The Xl Center And Rentschler Field To Be Managed By One Company.In February 2013, The Contract Was Awarded To Global Spectrum.
The Stadium Is Named After Frederick Brant Rentschler. Rentschler Was The Founder Of The Aircraft Company Pratt & Whitney, Which Created Revolutionary Aircraft Engines.

Robertson Stadium Was A Joint Project Between The Houston School District, And The Works Progress Administration (wpa), A Federal Agency Created Under President Rooseveltâ€™s New Deal. In March 1941, A Resolution Was Passed To Provide $650,000 For Stadium Construction.

Robertson Stadium Was Demolished In December 2010 To Make Way For The New Houston Stadium The Facility Is Expected To Open In August 2014. The Groundbreaking Ceremony Took Place On February 8, 2013. In March 2013, The Universityâ€™s Board Of Regents Finalized The New Stadiumâ€™s Location As The Former Robertson Stadium Site. The New Stadium Is Expected To Cost Upwards Of $100 Million. It Is Likely That Reliant Stadium In Houston Will End Up As The Cougars Home Stadium Forthe Upcoming Season.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.

The University Of Louisville Installed New Turf In Papa Johnâ€™s Stadium In April 2013.Additionally, The University Is In The Process Of Approving $7.5 Million In Revonations To The Howard L. Schnellenberger Football Complex Located At The North End Of The Stadium.
Papa Johnâ€™s Pizza Founder And Ceo John Schnatter, A Native Of Nearby Jeffersonville, Indiana, Donated $5 Million For The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
Liberty Bowl Memorial Stadium (rex Dockery Field)
The City Of Memphis Completely Funded The Project.

On January 8, 2013, Memphis City Officials Approved $12 Million In Funding For The Liberty Bowl To Renovate And Become Ada Compliant. The Goal Is To Remove 10,000 Seats In Order To Make Way For Handicapped Accessibility. The Project Is Expected To Be Completed By September 2013.

The City Of Memphis Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. In December Of 1983, City Of Memphis Officials Named The Playing Surface Rex Dockery Field In Honor Of The Late Tiger Coach Who Was Killed In A Plane Crash.
Rutgers, The State University Of New Jersey
Financing For The Stadium Came From The New Jersey Sports And Exposition Authority Bond Issue. The Bonds Accounted For 70% Of The Financing And Private Donations And Contributions Accounted For 30%.

Although Rutgers University Just Expanded High Point Solutions Stadium, Big Ten Commissioner Jim Delaney Has Stated That With Rutgers Joining The Conference In 2014, He Hopes The University Will Build A New Stadium. Currently, There Are No Plans To Do So.

In June Of 2011, Rutgers Stadium Was Renamed High Point Solutions Stadium After A Naming Rights Deal Was Announced. The Ten-year Deal Is Reportedly Worth $6.5 Million. In The Contract, A Clause That Stated That If Tim Pernetti Was No Longer The Athletic Director, High Point Solutions Would Have The Option To Break Their Contract With Rutgers. As Of June 2013, High Point Solutions Has Not Made A Decision As To Whether Or Not To Continue With The Relationship.
The Stadium Was 100% Privately Financed Through Donations And Gifts By Students, Former Student Athletes, And Other Alumni.

As Smu Is Set To Move To The Big East For 2013, The School Announced The Creation Of The 233-seat Hall Of Champions Club. In Addition, The School Will Add Seven New Suites. No Cost For The Project Has Been Announced.

The Stadium Is Named After Gerald J. Ford, A Banking Billionaire, Who Provided Significant Contributions To The Stadium Project. This Gerald Ford Is Not To Be Confused With Former President Gerald R. Ford.
The Stadium Was Publicly Funded Through A .05% Sales-tax Increase.

In February 2013, The Tampa Bay Buccaneers, The Main Tenant At Raymond James Stadium, Announced That Aramark Sports & Entertainment Will Now Handle Concessions At The Stadium. Aramark Is A Philadelphia Based Company That Handles The Concessions At Several Stadiums Throughout The Country. In Addition, Raymond James Is Expected To Be Remodeled By The Buccaneers To Include A New Team Store And Several Restaurants. Ten Fixed Retail Stores Are Also Expected To Be Added, In An Effort To Attract Patrons On Non-game Days.
Raymond James Financial Purchased The Naming Rights For $32.5 Million Over Thirteen Years. Raymond Jamesâ€™ Naming Rights Extend Through 2015.

The Facility, Also Used By The Nflâ€™s Philadelphia Eagles, Was Financed Through The State, The City, The Nfl, And The Eagles. The Mlbâ€™s Philadelphia Phillies' And The Eagles' New Stadiums Were Funded By A Combined $304 Million From The City, $482 Million From The Two Teams, And $170 Million From The State. The Eagles Contributed $310 Million.

In June 2012, The Philadelphia Eagles Announced That Lincoln Financial Field Would Be Undergoing Major Renovations. The Project Is Expected To Increase Seating And Add Additional Suites. The Preliminary Cost Projection Ranges From $60â€“$100 Million. The Project Also Includes The Installation Of New Video Boards And Upgrades To Gate Entries.

Lincoln Financial Group Agreed To Pay $139.6 Million Over Twenty Years For The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Agreement Expires In 2022 And Has An Average Annual Payout Of $6.7 Million. The Deal Also Includes Signs In The Stadium, Suites At Home And At Road Games, Tickets For The Pro Bowl, Commercial Time On The Eagles' Preseason Game Broadcasts And Television Shows, And Information Kiosks In The Stadium.

100% Privately Financed. The Stadium Was Part Of A $60 Million Project That Included Financing Costs, Reserve Requirements, Infrastructure, Roads, Parking, And Practice Fields For Football, Soccer, And Baseball. The Funding Came From The Stadiumâ€™s Naming Rights, Revenues From Suites And Club Seat Leases, Ticket And Concession Sales, Donations, Corporate Sponsorships, And Advertising. No Public Money Or Tuition Was Used To Build Or Operate The Stadium.

In Early 2013, Ucf Announced That They Were Undertaking An Engineering Study To See If An Open-air Tiki Bar On The East Side Of The Stadium. Early Estimates Have The Cost Of The Bar At Just Over $1 Million. The Goal Is To Have The Bar Open By The 2014 Season. Additionally, Ucf Has Proposed A $35 Million Expansion That Includes Additional Suites And Adding An Upper Deck To The Stadiumâ€™s East Side.
On August 8, 2006, Ucf Announced A Fifteen-year, $15 Million Stadium Naming Rights Deal With Cable Company Bright House. The Deal Expires In 2021.

Former Boston College Athletic Director William Flynn Led A Fundraising Campaign When The Eagles Could No Longer Play Their Games At Fenway Park. He Was Able To Raise $370,000 In Donations To Finance The Costs Of Alumni Stadium.

In The Summer Of 2012, The Artificial Surface Was Replace With A New Field. The Gameday Grass 3d60h Field Is Made From Horseshoe Fiber. The Mechanical Memory Of The Fiber Will Allow The Grass To Stand Upright Longer.
Boston College Owns The Naming Rights To Alumni Stadium.

Prior To The 2012 Season, Clemson University Announced That Daktronics, Inc. Would Be Installing A New Video, Scoring, And Sound System. The Large Screen Is Twenty-five Feet Tall By Sixty-one Feet Wide. The Screen Is Divided Into Multiple Windows In Order To Show Statistics, Highlights/replays, And Various Graphics. In Addition, Daktronics Also Installed Two More Screens Measuring Nineteen Feet Tall By Thirty-one Feet Wide In Two Of The Corners.
Clemson Owns The Naming Rights To Clemson Memorial Stadium.
The Facility Was Paid For Through Private Donations.

In October 2012, Duke University Announced A $250 Million Fundraising Campaign That Will See Upgrades To Several Athletic Faciltiies Including Wallace Wade Stadium. During The Project, The University Is Looking To Remove The Track Around The Football Field, Which Will Add Additional Seating, Press Boxes, And Suites. In Addition, A New Building Will Be Erected Between The Football And Basketball Stadiums That Will House Athletics Offices, Training And Weight Rooms, And A New Store. The Horshoe Stadium Will Also Be Enclosed To Form A Bowl.
From 1929 To 1967 The Stadium Was Named Duke Stadium. Then, In 1967 The Board Of Trustees Unanimously Agreed To Rename The Stadium After Former Legendary Coach Wallace Wade.
Bobby Bowden Field At Doak S. Campbell Stadium
Local Boosters Were Able To Raise $50,000 Of The Costs By Selling 1,000 Five-year Season Tickets At The Price Of $50 Per Ticket.

Florida State University Owns The Naming Rights To The Field And Stadium. It Named The Stadium After Former University President Doak Campbell And Renamed The Field After Former Head Coach Bobby Bowden In 2004.
Bobby Dodd Stadium At Historic Grant Field
The Facility Was Entirely Financed By Georgia Tech. The Major Donation For Construction Came From John W. Grant, Who Gave $15,000.

Georgia Techâ€™s Football Facility Was Known As Grant Field Until April 1988, When The Georgia State Board Of Regents Voted To Add The Name Bobby Dodd To The Stadium In Honor Of The Legendary Coach. Georgia Tech Students Assisted With The Original Construction. Georgia Tech Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
Capital One Field At Byrd Stadium
Prior To The 2012 Season, Maryland University Announced That The Playing Surface At Capital One Field Had Been Replaced. The Field Was Replaced With A Heat-reducing Synthetic Turf.

The Stadium Was Originally Named After Harry â€œcurleyâ€ù Byrd, A Multi-sport Athlete, Football Coach, And University President In The First Half Of The 20th Century. In 2006, Maryland Entered Into A Naming Rights Agreement With Chevy Chase Bank For $20 Million. The Stadium Name Was Changed When Capital One Acquired Chevy Chase Bank.
Stephen Ross (principal) And H. Wayne Huizenga
$115 Million; Completed $250 Million Of Capital Improvements In 2007
90% Privately Funded With Money Generated By Leasing Luxury Boxes And Clubhouse Seats. The Remaining 10% Came From The State Of Florida.

In March 2013, The Florida State Government Approved A Bill That Will Provide A $3 Million Per Year Tax Rebate And County Wide 1-cent Tax Increase In Order To Help Fund Renovation Projects At Sun Life Stadium. The Upgrades Are Expected To Include The Addition Of A Canopy Over The Stadium, Increased Seating, And The Addition Of New Video Board Around The Stadium. In May 2013, The Expected Renovations Were Halted By The Florida State Government By Rejecting A Bill That Included A Bid For Public Financing.
In 2010, Sun Life Financial Entered Into A Five-year Contract For Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Contract Will Pay $7.5 Million Per Year For The Naming Rights.
University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill
University Of North Carolina At Chapel Hill

The University Of North Carolina Completely Financed The Stadium. In June 1926, Nearly Forty Alumni Contributed Just Under $30,000. When William Kenan Visited The Facility In November, He Decided To Fund The Rest Of The Stadium To Establish A Memorial For His Late Parents.
The University Decided To Name The Stadium After The Kenan Family For Their Generous Donations And Dedication To The University And Its Athletic Programs.
North Carolina State University Completely Financed The Stadium.

North Carolina State University Initially Named The Stadium After Harry And Wilbert Carter, Both Graduates Of The University And Then Added The Name Of Albert E. Finley, Another Major Contributor To The University. North Carolina State Owns The Naming Rights.
Sports & Exhibition Authority Of Pittsburgh And Allegheny County (nflâ€™s Pittsburgh Steelers)
The Steelers Contributed $76.5 Million For The Stadium, The State Provided $75 Million, And The Remainder Came From The Allegheny Regional Asset District, Which Administered A 1% County Sales Tax.
In September 2012, The Pittsburgh Steelers Announced That An Additional 3,000 Seats Would Be Added To Heinz Field.
H.J. Heinz Bought The Exclusive Naming Rights For The Steelersâ€™ Home Field For $57 Million. The Deal Expires In 2021 And Has An Average Annual Payout Of $2.9 Million.

Syracuse University Completed Renovations To The Carrier Dome Before The Start Of The 2012 Football Season. Most Notably, The School Added Two Large Video Screens To Both Ends Of The Stadium. In Addition, Wireless Technology Was Added Throughout The Stadium. In April 2012, The School Announced That The Locker Rooms Would Be Upgraded And A Cafeteria Would Be Added. The Student-athlete Lounge Will Also Be Remodeled. In Totality, The Renovation Is Expected To Cost Around $5 Million.
The Carrier Corporation Made A $2.75 Million Naming Gift.
Carl Smith Center, Home Of David A. Harrison Iii Field At Scott Stadium
The University Of Virginia Completely Financed Scott Stadium.

The Official Name Of The Field And Stadium Is The Carl Smith Center, Home Of David A. Harrison Iii Field At Scott Stadium. Scott Stadium Bears The Name Of The Donor And University Rector Frederic Scott. David A. Harrison Iii Provided A Gift Allowing Natural Grass To Be Reinstalled In The Stadium. The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
Virginia Polytechnic Institute And State University
The University Was Responsible For The Stadium Financing Through Donations And Contributions From Alumni.

Virginia Tech Is In The Process Of Installing A 48.2 Feet Tall By 108.2 Feet Wide High Definition Led Replacement Of Their Current Video Board. Installation Is Set To Be Complete Before The 2013 Season And Cost Approximately $3 Million. Additionally, The Sound System In Lane Stadium Will Be Upgraded As Well.

The Stadium Is Named For The Late Edward H. Lane, A Graduate Of The University. Lane Led An Educational Foundation Project That Raised More Than $3 Million For The Original Construction. The Field Was Named Worsham Field In 1992, To Honor Wes And Janet Worsham, Who Donated $1 Million To The University's Second Century Campaign.
Wake Forest University Completely Financed The Stadium.

Wake Forest University Is Still Involved In A Seven-phase Upgrade To The Football Stadium And Surrounding Area. Three Phases Remain To Be Completed; All Are Subject To Funding. The First Phase Is To Upgrade Deacon Hill, A Fan Interaction Area. Next, The Renovation Will Include Remodeling The Locker Room Areas. Lastly, The Renovations Will Upgrade Tailgating Areas Around The Stadium.
Bb&t Bank Owns The Naming Rights To The Demon Deaconâ€™s Field.
A Bond Sales Program Raised $1.5 Million For The Costs.

As Baylor University Is Currently Constructing A New Football Stadium, Preliminarily Named Baylor Stadium, The City Of Waco Has Informed Baylor That Unless They Can Find A Use For Floyd Casey Stadium, The Likely Result Will Be The Tearing Down Of Said Stadium. As For The New Stadium, An Update In October 2012 Noted That Sewer And Utility Lines Were Installed. As For Seat Licenses, Baylor University Announced In December 2012 That The Seats Were Selling Fast, With A Limited Number Still Available.

Originally Named Baylor Stadium, In 1989, The Stadium Was Renamed Floyd Casey Stadium After Longtime University Supporter And Trustee Carl B. Casey And His Wife Contributed $5 Million Of An $8 Million Renovation Project In Honor Of His Father Floyd.

In 2007, Iowa State Announced A Renovation Plan To Jack Trice Stadium. Although Phase I Was Completed In 2007, Phase Ii Still Lacks The Necessary Funding To Commence. During This Phase Of The Renovation, Iowa State Is Expected To Close Off The End Zone And Make The Horseshoe Stadium A Bowl. Also, Officials Announced A Remodeling Of All Concessions And Restrooms.
The Stadium Is Named In Honor Of Jack Trice, Iowa Stateâ€™s First African- American Athlete.

Funding Started With Colonel John Mccook, Who Donated $2,500 To Start A Funding Drive. In 1920, Students And Faculty Started A Drive To Build A New Facility And Collected More Than $200,000 To Build What Would Eventually Become The First Concrete Structure.

In July 2012, Kansas Ad Sheahon Zenger Announced That Memorial Stadium Would Be Getting A Makeover. Among The Discussed Changes Are Removal Of The Track Around The Field, The Addition Of More Bleacher Seating, And The Addition Of More Suites. As Of Right Now, There Is No Date Set To Start Renovations, But The School Is Firmly In The Discussion Phase For The Changes.
The Stadium Has Had Several Names, But Kansas Ultimately Changed The Name To Memorial And Dedicated The Stadium To The Students Who Fought And Died In World War I.
The Stadium Was 100% Privately Financed Through Student Fees, Athletics Gate Receipts, And Contributions.

Continuing In 2012 And 2013 Are Phase Ii And Iii Of The Stadium Renovation. Phase Ii Includes Upgrading Concessions And Restrooms, And Renovating Seating. Also, A New Team Store, Hall Of Fame, And Ticket Office Will Be Added. Phase Iii Will Include The Addition Of A Strength And Conditioning Center. Also, A New Recruiting Lunge Will Be Added.
In 2005, The Stadium Was Renamed In Honor Of Legendary Head Football Coach Bill Snyder By A Proclamation Of The Kansas Board Of Regents.
In 1921, University Students Started A Movement For Construction Of A Student Union. By 1925, The Idea Grew To Include A Combined Football Stadium And Union.

The Stadium Was Originally Named Oklahoma Memorial Stadium To Honor University-associated Persons Who Died In World War I. The Stadium Underwent A Name Change After The Gaylord Family Donated $50 Million Toward Renovations.

The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed. The Stadium Was Rededicated In 2009 After An Aggressive Fundraising Effort Led By Boone Pickens. He Made A $70 Million Gift And Spurred The â€œnext Level Campaign,â€ù Which Generated More Than $100 Million In Gifts And Pledges. Pickens Capped The Effort In 2005 With A Monumental Gift Of $165 Million.

Oklahoma State Owns The Naming Rights. The Stadium Is Named After Boone Pickens In Recognition Of His Generous Donations To The Universityâ€™s Athletic Department, One Of Which Was The Single Largest Gift To An Athletics Department Ever.

The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed When Amon G. Carter Began A Quiet Campaign To Raise The Money For A Stadium That Would Seat Roughly 30,000. Fort Worth Residents Were Set To Raise 60% Of The Money For The Stadium. Eventually The Sides Settled On Selling Mortgage Bonds To Construct A $350,000 Stadium That Would Seat 27,000, But Had The Capacity To Expand To 60,000.
Tcu Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium Named After Amon G. Carter For His Significant Contributions To The Athletics Department.
The University Of Texas At Austin
Darrell K Royal - Texas Memorial Stadium
The University Of Texas At Austin
Completely Financed Through Private Donations And Gifts.

In May 2013, The University Of Texasâ€™ Board Of Regents Approved A $62 Million Proposal For Improvements To Royal-texas Memorial Stadium. The Imporovements Will Not Add Seating To The Stadium, Which Seats Just Over 100,000 At Capacity, But Includes Adding A Practice Gym For The Womenâ€™s Volleyball Team And Additional Athletics Offices.
The University Of Texas At Austin Owns The Naming Rights.
Completely Financed By Private Gifts. At&t Was The Main Contributor.

In January 2013, Construction At Jones At&t Stadium Commenced. Texas Tech Announced A $5 Million Project That Will Add 368 Seats And An Observation Deck. In Addition, The School Announced The Addition Of Eleven Columns To The North End Of The Stadium That Will Retain Techâ€™s Spanish Renaissance Style.

The Stadium Was Officially Renamed From Jones Stadium To Jones Sbc Stadium In 2000 Following Major Corporate Gifts (in Excess Of $25 Million) From Sbc Communications (now At&t). The Stadium Was Renamed Again In 2006 To Jones At&t Stadium After Sbc Changed Its Name To At&t. The â€œjonesâ€ù In Jones Stadium Comes From Former Texas Tech President Clifford B. Jones.
Mountaineer Field At Milan Puskar Stadium
The University Completely Funded The Stadium, While Milan Puskar Completely Funded The Renovations.
The Stadium Was Renamed â€œmilan Puskar Stadiumâ€ù In 2004 After Puskar Made A $20 Million Donation To The University.

Donations Of Approximately $1.7 Million Contributed By More Than 200,000 Students, Alumni, And Other Friends Of The University Made The Construction Possible. The Athletic Association Later Allocated $509,850 To The Project For The Construction Of The South Stands And Other Stadium Additions.

At The Commencement Of The 2013 Football Season, The Fighting Illini Will Unveil A New Thirty-six Feet Tall By Ninety-six Feet Wide Hd Video Display, As Well As Two Auxillary Video Displays And Several Led Ribbon Displays Throughout The Stadium.

The Stadium Was Built And Named As A Memorial To Illinois Men And Women Who Gave Their Lives For Their Country During World War I. Their Names Appear On 200 Columns That Support The East And West Sides Of The Stadium
Indiana University Owns The Naming Rights To Memorial Stadium. The Stadium Was Named To Honor Those Who Served In World War I.
100% Privately Financed Through Donations And Gifts To The University.
In April 2013, Iowaâ€™s Board Of Regents Approved An $8 Million Proposal That Will Update The Kinnick Stadium Video Board And Sound Equipment. The Project Has Been Undertaken By Daktronics, Inc.
The University Of Iowa Owns The Naming Rights For The Stadium And Named It After 1939 Heisman Trophy Winner Nile Kinnick After He Died Serving His Country In World War Ii.

Fielding Yost, A Successful Businessman Interested In Coal, Oil, And Real Estate, Devised A Plan To Finance The Construction And Facilities Through A $1.5 Million Issue Of 3,000 Bonds At A Par Value Of $500 At 3% Interest. The Money Ended Up Being Not Only Enough For The Stadium, But Also For Other Athletic Facilities.
The University Of Michigan Owns The Naming Rights To Michigan Stadium.

Final Approval For A $20 Million Renovation Project For Spartan Stadium Is Expected In June Of 2013. The Project Will Include The Addition Of A New $10 Million Scoreboard. New Locker Rooms, Concession Areas, A Media Room, And Sports Recruiting Room Are To Be Added. Funding For The Renovation Will Be Split Between Private Donations And Athletic Department Funds And Is Expected To Be Completed In The Spring Of 2014.
Michigan State University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.

On March 24, 2005, Tcf Bank Announced That It Would Contribute $35 Million Toward The Stadium Project, Which Would Give Them Naming Rights As Well. The State Declared That It Would Contribute 48% Of The Stadium Costs While The University Would Raise The Remaining 52%. The Universityâ€™s Portion Of The Funding Came From The Tcf Donation, A $50 Per Semester Student Fee, Private Donations, And The Sale Of University Property. Many Private Corporations Financed The Stadium For Advertising Rights Within. Private Financing Totaled $111 Million.

In 2013, The Minnesota Vikings And University Of Minnesota Announced An Agreement That Will Allow The Vikings To Use Tcf Bank For Two Years ($300,000 Per Game) While A New Stadium For The Vikings Is Completed In Downtown Minneapolis.
Tcf Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium Worth $35 Million Over Twenty-five Years.
In The Fall Of 1922, Faculty, Students, Alumni, And Friends Of The University Held A Fund Drive That Collected $430,000 In Construction Funds For The Stadium.

Expansion Of The East Side Of Memorial Stadium Continued In 2013. Brick And Concrete Work Has Been Completed, And Seating Is Expected To Be Added Next. The Expansion Is Set To Include Thirty-eight New Suites, And 5,000 New Seats.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. Memorial Stadium Was Named In Honor Of The Men And Women Who Fought And Served In World War I And The Spanish-american War.
The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed Through Fund Raising Drives And Private Donations.

Although Renovations Were Announced In 2010, Progress Has Been Slow. As Of Early 2013, No Physical Progress Has Been Made On Renovating Ryan Field. In Response, The Board Of Trustees Released A Statement Saying That They Want To Do Things Right With The Renovation; Hence, There Has Been A Long Delay In The Renovating Process.
Patrick Ryan, Who Was The Chairman Of The Schoolâ€™s Board Of Trustees, Paid $8 Million For The Rights In 1997.
Local Businessmen Raised The $1.3 Million Through Private Donations.

The 2013 Spring Football Game At Ohio Stadium Was Moved As Ohio State University Completes Renovations To The Stadium. The Most Notable Upgrade Is The Replacing Of Seating In The Stadium. In Addition, Ohio State Added A New $7 Million Scoreboard Ahead Of The 2012 Season. Furthermore, The Athletic Department Has Recently Proposed A $9 Million, 2,500-seat Expansion To Ohio Stadium, Which Would Move The Stadium To The Third Largest Stadium In The Country With Capacity Of 104,829.

In 2012, Penn State Announced Plans To Renovate The Scoreboard Have Been Pushed Back Until 2014. The Plan Now Is To Finish Renovations To The Practice Football Facility Before Beginning The Replacement Of The Scoreboard At Beaver Stadium.
Pennsylvania State University Owns The Naming Rights To The Facility And It Is Named After James A. Beaver, A Former Governor Of Pennsylvania And President Of The Universityâ€™s Board Of Trustees.

In May 2013, Purdue Athletic Director Morgan Burke Outlined Potential Plans For Ross-ade Stadium. While No Plans Have Been Approvedat This Point, Some Of The Renovations Discussed Include An Indoor Club With A Rooftop Terrace That Would Seat Approzimately 2,000 As Well As A New Larger Video Board In The South Endzone. No Timetable Or Costs Have Been Released For The Planned Renovations.

Ross-ade Was Dedicated At The 1924 Game Against In-state Rival Indiana. The Stadium Is Named For Its Two Principal Benefactors, Alumni David E. Ross, The Late President Of The Board Of Trustees, And The Late George Ade, Playwright And Humorist. Ross Conceived The Idea For The Stadium, And Ade Purchased And Presented To The University The Sixty-five-acre Tract On Which The Stadium Is Located.

Column: The land was given to the university after the Civil War ended and the track and field teams originally used it until football moved in. The university asked the state for $40,000 and received half of its original request.

value: In Early 2012, The University Of Wisconsin Announced An $86 Million Renovation To Camp Randall. Most Of The Renovations Will Take Place Outside Of The Stadium. The Most Notable Project Is A Three-story Academic And Strength Center For Student-athletes. In Addition, The Team Locker Room And Training Rooms Will Be Upgraded And Remodeled. The North Endzone Will Also Be Outfitted With A New Scoreboard.
The University Of Wisconsin Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Stadium Received Its Name Because It Lies On The Grounds Of Camp Randall, A Union Army Training Camp During The Civil War.
All Of The Funds For The Facility Were Privately Raised. The Goal Was To Raise $200,000; The Fundraiser Ultimately Collected $238,000.

In The Fall Of 2012, An Ecu Student Vandalized Dowdy-fricklen Stadium. Damage Was Calculated At Nearly $35,000. The Student Vandalized Concession Areas, Then Drove A Cart Over The Field Tearing Up Grass.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Stadium Is Named After Ron And Mary Ellen Dowdy After They Pledged A $1 Million Gift To The Ecu Scholarship Foundation. The Stadium Is Also Named For James Skinner Ficklen, The Owner Of Greenvilleâ€™s E.B. Skinner Tobacco Company. Skinner Was A Booster Of The College And Established A Scholarship Fund In His Name.

To Help Fund The Stadium, Fau Secured A $12 Million Development Rights Deal With Crocker Partners, Llc. The Funding From The Deal Provides Fau With The Money It Needs To Secure A Bond For The Stadium. On July 1, 2010, Fau Trustees Voted To Approve A $44.6 Million Finance Plan From Regions Bank.
Fauâ€™s New Stadium Opened In The Fall Of 2011. The $70 Million, 30,000-seat Stadium Is On The Fau Campus.

Fau Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. In April 2013, Plans To Have The Stadium Named For The Geo Group Fell Through After A Public Relations Outcry. The Geo Group Is A Prison Company, And Many Felt The Name Was Inappropriate For A School Systemâ€™s Building. The Naming Deal Was Originally For $6 Million.
The Stadium Was Originally Built As Part Of The County Parks System.

Fiu Has A Four-phase Plan For Renovation. Phases One Through Three Are Complete And Phase Four Is Planned For 2013. Phase Four, Set To Begin In 2013, Will Include Increasing The Seating Capacity To 45,000; Expanding The Upper Concourse, And Constructing Additional Luxury Suites And Club Suites, The Fiu Alumni Center, A Restaurant Overlooking The Field, Main Street Fiu, And A Two-story Expansion Of The Fieldhouse.
Fiu Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.

The Stadium Is Named After Joe Aillet, A Member Of The Louisiana Tech Athletics Hall Of Fame And The National Football Foundation College Football Hall Of Fame. He Guided His Teams To A 151-86-9 Record And Nine Conference Championships During His Coaching Tenure.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Stadium Was Officially Named Johnny â€œredâ€ù Floyd Stadium In 1979 To Honor Johnny â€œredâ€ù Floyd, The Schoolâ€™s Most Prominent Football Coach.

The Facility Will Be Financed Through The Sale Of Suites, Club, And Luxury Boxes, As Well As Through Gifts And Donations To The University. In May 2009, Governor Rick Perry Signed Into Law A Bill Requiring Unt Students To Pay A $10 Student Athletic Fee To Help Fund The Construction Project.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And Came To A Twenty-year Deal With Apogee In 2011.

Rice Stadium Is Set To Receive Major Upgrades In A $44.5 Million Project. The Major Changes Will Take Place In The South End Zone. An 80,000-square Foot Complex Will Be Built On The South Side Of The Stadium That Includes Training And Locker Rooms, A Sports Medicine Center, Offices For Coaching Staff And Support Personnel, And A Hall Of Fame.
Rice University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And Chose To Name The Stadium After The University.
Originally Built In 1932; Demolished And Rebuilt In 1976.
$6.3 Million When It Was Rebuilt In 1976; $32.5 Million Expansion In 2008

100% Privately Financed. All Funds Were Raised Through A Capital Finance Campaign. The Stadium Paid For Its Reconstruction In 1976 Through A Renovation Capital Campaign Called â€œbuilding Dominance,â€ù Which Financed Several Other Projects On The Campus.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And Named The Stadium After M.M. Roberts, Who Provided Significant Contributions To The Stadium Refinancing.
The Stadium Was Financed Through A Bond Issued Backed By A Hotel Tax.
Mercedes-benz Obtained The Naming Rights For The Superdome In A Ten Year Deal That Is Expected To Expire In 2020. Terms Of The Deal Have Not Been Released.
Skelly Field At H.A. Chapman Stadium
All Financing For The Stadium Was Collected Through Private Gifts And Donations.

The Chapman Family Trust Provided Major Monetary Contributions For The Naming Rights To The Stadium. William Skelly Also Pledged To Donate $125,000 For The Construction If Another $175,000 Could Be Raised. The Other Money Was Raised And Skelly Donated The Money To The University.
N/a â€“ Likely Publicly Financed Because The City Of Birmingham Owns The Stadium.

Although Legion Field Has Been Home To The Blazers Since Their Inaugural Season In 1991, Uab Is Looking To Add A Football Stadium On Campus. The New Master Plan Includes A Horseshoe-shaped, On-campus Football Stadium. The Proposed Cost For The Stadium Is Near $75 Million.
Because The City Owns The Stadium, In 1927 It Was Named In Honor Of The American Legion And Stands As A Memorial To Those Who Gave Their Lives In The Service Of America.
University Of Texas At El Paso
Much Of The Stadium Is Financed Through The Various Sponsorships Generated By The Sun Bowl.
The Sun Bowl Association Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
University Of Texas At San Antonio
The Alamodome Was 100% Financed By The City Of San Antonio When It Was Constructed In 1993. The City Still Owns And Operates The Facility.
Utsa, In 2012, Signed A Long-term Lease Deal Until 2035. The Deal Essentially Ends Years Of Talks That The School Would Build Its Own Stadium.

The City Owns The Naming Rights To The Facility, Which Is Used For Several Different Purposes, And Its Name Comes From The Historical Nickname Given To San Antonio After The Famous â€œbattle Of The Alamo.â€ù

The Original Stadium Was Dedicated In Honor Of Dennis Mahan Michie, Who Was Instrumental In Starting The Game Of Football At Army In 1890. He Organized, Managed, And Coached The First Team. In 1999, The Field Was Named â€œblaik Fieldâ€ù In Honor Of Earl "red" Blaik, The Winningest Coach In Army Annals.
The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed Through Donations And Gifts.
Prior To The 2012 Season Byu Installed New Video Boards On Both Ends Of The Stadium.
Originally Known As Cougar Stadium, The Stadium Was Renamed For Legendary Head Football Coach Lavell Edwards Upon His Retirement At The Conclusion Of The 2000 Season.
William H. Kibbie-asui Activity Center (â€œkibbie Domeâ€ù)
100% Privately Financed Through University Donations And Gifts.

The Kibbie-asui Activity Center Was Named After William H. Kibbie, A Former Student Who Donated $300,000 Toward Building Of The Facility. Kibbie Attended The University Of Idaho For A Few Weeks In 1936 Before Having To Withdraw Due To Family Hardship.
The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed. Most Of The Financing For Construction And Renovations Has Come Through The Naval Academy Foundation And The Naval Academy Athletic Association.

In June 2012 Navy Announced Plans To Expand The Stadium By 4,000 Seats. The $16 Million Dollar Project Will Also Include New Video Boards In The End Zones And New Club Level Seating. Inside The Stadium, The Press Box And Locker Rooms Will Be Renovated.
The Facility Is Named In Memory And Honor Of Those Who Died While Serving United States.
Funded By The New Mexico Legislature As Part Of A Capital Outlay Project.

In 2012, A Request For $6 Million For Improvements To Aggie Memorial Stadium Was Approved. $2.5 Million Will Go Towards Press Box Upgrades, While The Remaining $3.5 Million Will Go Towards Concession And Restroom Improvements.

The Facility Was 100% Privately Financed Through University Donors And Alumni. The Subsequent Renovations Were Financed By $53 Million In Tax-exempt, Fixed-rate Bonds. The Bonds Were Sold In Twenty-six States.

In May Of 2013, The University Released A Proposed Plan To Expand Notre Dame Stadium. The Proposal Includes Building New Student Assembly, Visitor And Media Centers, As Well As The Addition Of 3,000 Club Seats.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.

Infocision Paid $10 Million For Naming Rights To The Stadium, Summa Health System Paid $5 Million For The Naming Rights To The Field, Firstmerit Foundation Paid $1 Million For The Naming Rights To The Club Level, And Towpath Credit Union Paid $100,000 For The Naming Rights To The Press Box.
The Facility And Its Renovations Were Funded By Private Donors And Gifts Provided To The University By Students, Faculty, And Alumni.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. After The 2007 Renovations, The Stadium Was Renamed For Former Athletic Standout John Scheumann And His Wife June In Recognition Of Their $4 Million Gift To The Project.
Bowling Green State Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And The Stadium Is Named After Former Coaching Great Doyt L. Perry For His Work With The Team From 1955 To 1964.

100% School Financed. The Funding Was Provided Through The New York State Dormitory Authority, Which Provides Financing And Construction Services To Public And Private Universities, Not For Profit Healthcare Facilities And Other Institutions That Serve The Public Good.

In Late 2012, The University Unveiled Plans To Expand Ub Stadium. The Plans Suggest An Addition To The Stadiums East Side And Premium Amenities, Including A Hospitality Area. The University Hopes To Complete The Project By 2015. Additionally, The University Of Buffalo Announced That The Equipment Room Would Be Named After The Ronald Balter Family.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
As Of 2013, Progress Has Stalled On The Stadium Hotel Project. Once Fully Financed, The Hotel Will Be Built Near The Stadium.

The Stadium Was Dedicated In November 1972 And Named Perry Shorts Stadium In Honor Of R. Perry Shorts, A Former Cmu Athlete. In 1983, The Cmu Board Of Trustees Voted To Rename The Facility Kelly/shorts Stadium In Honor Of Bill Kelly, Who Coached At Cmu From 1951 To 1966.
Emu Owns The Rights To The Stadium, And It Is Named For The Late Elton J. Rynearson, Sr., Who Coached Football At Emu For Twenty-six Seasons.
Kent State Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And The Stadium Is Named In Honor Of Former Kent State Board Of Trustees Member Robert Dix. The Stadium Was Originally Named Memorial Stadium.
The New England Patriots Paid For The $325 Million Stadium.
Global Gillette Receives Naming Rights For $240 Million Until The Year 2013. The Average Annual Value Is Expected To Be $8 Million.
The Stadium Was 100% Privately Financed Through Benefactors And Other Private Donors.
The Stadium Is Named For Alumnus Fred C. Yager, Who Was The Lead Benefactor In The Project To Build The Stadium.
For The 2013 Season, Niu Is Adding A $3.3 Million Led Jumbotron.

The Stadium And Field Have Had Several Name Changes During The Stadiumâ€™s Existence. The University Owns The Naming Rights And The Stadium Itself Is Named For The Northern Illinois Mascot. The Playing Surface Is Named In Honor Of Robert J. Brigham, A Former Player, Coach, And Athletic Director At The School.
The Facility Was 100% Financed By The University.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Stadium Was Named After Former Bobcat Head Coach Don Peden. A Coach And Director Of Athletics At Ohio For Twenty-seven Years, He Was One Of The Founders Of The Mid-american Conference And Was Monumental In The Development Of College Athletics.
The Project Was Paid For With $272,000 From The Federal Government And $41,558 From The City Of Toledo And The University.

In 1946, Wayne Kohn, A Libby Owens Ford Engineer, Conceived The Idea Of Using Glass To Rebuild The Stadium. Glass Blocks Were Installed Throughout The Stadium And A Glass Electric Scoreboard Was Built In The South End Zone. A New Two-tier Press Box Of Blue Vitrolite And Glass Blocks Was Also Constructed. Lights Were Installed, Beginning A Tradition Of Night Football At Ut. It Is Now Known As The Glass Bowl.
The Facility Was 100% Financed Through Donations And Gifts To The University. The Donors Who Contributed Money For The Construction Of The Stadium Were Awarded Season Tickets By Wmu.
In June 2013, Wmu Athletics Began Replacing The Turf In Waldo Stadium.
Western Michigan Owns The Naming Rights And Dedicated The Stadium To Wmu President Emeritus Dwight B. Waldo, The Schoolâ€™s First President And A Strong Advocate Of Broncos Athletics.
The Stadium Was 100% Funded Through Donations By Air Force Personnel And Civilian Sources.

In August 2012, Air Force Announced That They Hoped To Start Falcon Stadium Renovations After The 2012 Season. The Renovations Are Expected To Cost Around $20 Million. First, The Project Is Set To Remove The East Grandstand To Allow For An Open-air Concourse. Next, Air Force Wants To Add More Press Box Space, And Private Skyboxes. Lastly, The School Is Going To Add More Concession Areas And Restrooms.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. There Are Currently Talks Among The Academy Administration About Changing The Name. Since Fisher Deberry Earned Election To The College Football Hall Of Fame, University Proponents Have Crusaded To Name The Stadium After Him Because Of His Coaching Success At The Afa. However, Opponents Feel It Should Remain Falcon Stadium.

Prior To The 2012 Season, Boise State Added 3,500 Seats. Also, The Track Was Painted Grey In Order To Blend In More With The Surroundings; The Track Is No Longer In Use. The New 70,000 Square Foot Football Facility At The North End Of The Stadium, Which Includes Coaches' Offices, Meeting Rooms, A Player Lounge, Recruiting Lounge, Training Facility With Weight Room, An Academic And Computer Lab, And A Brand New Locker Room, Is Expected To Be Finished In Late 2013.
Sonny Lubick Field At Hughes Stadium
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Is Named After Harry Hughes, A Former Head Coach At Csu For Thirty-one Years.
The Facility Was Paid For By The State Of Hawaiâ€™i Because It Is A Major Attraction That Hosts Various Events That Generate Money For The Hawaiian Economy.
A Current Plan To Replace 3,000 Seats Per Year Continues In 2013.
The State Of Hawaiâ€™i Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
100% Privately Financed By The University Through Private Donations.

In May 2013, A Plan To Pursue $6â€“$8 Million In Renovations To Mackay Stadium Was Introduced By The Athletics Department. The Plan Includes The Addition Of New Suites Ans A Club Seating Level, As Well As New Chairback In At Least Five Sections Of The Stadium.
Since The Early 1900s, Nevadaâ€™s Football Team Has Played In Facilities Named After University Benefactor Clarence Mackay.
The Project Was 100% Funded By The University.
In 2012, Installation Of A New Artificial Turf Field Was Completed. The Field Was Also Renamed Branch Field After A $1.5 Million Donation From Margaret And Turner Branch.
The University Of New Mexico Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
The City Of San Diego Issued A $27 Million Bond To Finance Construction Of The Stadium.
Discussions About Renovating Qualcomm Stadium Continued In Late 2012; No Plans Have Been Finalized.
Qualcomm Corporation Paid $18 Million Cash For Twenty-year Naming Rights In 1997. The Deal Expires In 2017 And Has An Average Annual Payout Of $900,000.

The University Expects To Break Ground On Its Recently Approved $38.5 Million Renovation Plan By The End Of 2013. The Construction Calls For Improvements To To Vermeil Walsh Athletic Complex, Including New Locker Rooms, Coaches Offices, Meeting Rooms, Training Facilities, And A Hall Of Fame, And To The West West Side Of The Stadium, Which Will Receive A New Entry Plaza, Ticket Windows. The North Side Renovations Will Also Include New Consession Stands And Restrooms.
Sjsu Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
The Facility Was Financed Through Private Donations.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. When The $3.5 Million Stadium Was Built In 1971 It Was Originally Named Las Vegas Stadium. The Stadium Was Renamed The Las Vegas Silver Bowl In 1978, And In 1984 It Was Renamed Sam Boyd Stadium In Honor Of Local Gaming Pioneer Sam Boyd.
For The 2012 Season, Utah State Installed A New Field Turf.
The Stadium Was Named After Dick Romney, Who Coached The Aggies To Four Conference Championships, Compiling A 128-91-16 Record In Twenty-nine Seasons.
Jonah Field At War Memorial Stadium
A $5 Million Gift Was Donated To The University And Matched By The State To Rename The Playing Surface Jonas Field. The Stadium Itself Is Named In Honor Of Those Who Have Served Our Country.
As Of June 2013, A Long-term Renovation Project Has Been Completed At Arizona Stadium. The Renovations Include The Enclosure Of The North End To Make A Stadium Bowl, New Seats, And A New Locker Room.
The City And State Paid For The Stadium.

In April 2012, Renderings Were Released For Proposed Renovations To Sun Devil Stadium. The Renderings Are Very Modern And Include A Futuristic-looking Canopy. The New Stadium Could Cost As Much As $300 Million. In April 2013, The Asu Confirmed The Plan To Temporarily Move Asu Football To Chase Field, Home Of Mlbâ€™s Arizona Diamondbacks, Starting In 2015 To Make Way For The Renovations.

When The University Launched A Statewide Campaign In October 1921 To Build A Football Stadium On Campus In Honor Of The Wwi Participants Who Lost Their Lives, The Responses And Results Were Staggering. In Only One Month, Generous Supporters Of The University Pledged More Than $1 Million, And Just Two Years Later, The Stadium Was Built.

After Twenty-one Months Of Construction, And Over $300 Million In Funding, The University Of California Reopened A Remodeled Memorial Stadium. New Seats Were Installed, And Concession Areas/restrooms Were Completely Redone.
The University Owns The Naming Rights And The Stadium Is Named After Those Who Served And Died In Service To Their Country In World War I.

In February 2013, Colorado Ad Mike Bohn Released Plans For A $170 Million Renovation To Folsom Field. The Most Significant Addition To The Stadium Will Be A New Student- Athlete Academic Center Located On The East Side Of The Stadium.

The University Owns The Naming Rights And The Stadium Is Named After Legendary Coach Fred Folsom. However, In The Spring Of 2011, The Denver Post Reported That Frontier Airlines Is A Possible Front-runner To Purchase The Naming Rights To The Stadium. Other Companies Are In Consideration As Well. Keeping The Name Folsom Field Will Be A Priority, But The Stadium May Take On Any Name The Sponsor Deems Appropriate For Its Product. As Of June 2012, The Name Of The Stadium Has Not Changed.

The Oregon Board Of Higher Education Approved A $5 Million Gift By Nike Co- Founder Phil Knight In January 2013. Knight Has Gifted The University With Various Amounts Over The Years To Help Fund Capital Projects On Campus. This Gift Will Go To The Improvement Of Foot Traffic At Autzen Stadium.
The University Owns The Rights To The Facility And It Is Named After The Thomas J. Autzen Foundation, Which Contributed $250,000 Of The Original $2.5 Million Raised To Construct The Stadium.

Although No Renovation Plan Has Been Formally Announced, Ad Bob De Carolis Issued A Report In Late 2012 About A Possible Renovation. The Released Statement Noted That Osu Is Conducting A Study Into Expansion Of The Stadium. As Well, There Is A Plan To Add To The Valley Football Center Facilities. A Cost For A Proposed Renovation Has Not Been Figured Out Eithe.
Formerly Known As Parker Stadium, Reser Got Its Name In 1999 When Pat Reser Of Beaverton, Oregon, Made A Personal Seven-figure Gift To Osu Athletics.

Currently, The Rose Bowl Is Undergoing $180 Million In Renovations. As Of February 2013, The Project Was Still Focusing On Completing The Press Box And Pavilion Areas. In Addition, Foundations And Underground Utilities Have Been Added To The West Side Restrooms.

The City Of Pasadena Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Was Named â€œrose Bowlâ€ù By Police Reporter Harlan W. Hall, Who Had The Yale Bowl In Mind When Thinking Of How An Expanded Structure Would Look.

Usc Signed A New Lease With The Coliseum In 2012. The Deal Calls For Usc To Invest $70 Million To Renovate The Stadium, Take Over The Coliseum's $1-million Rent To The State, And Give The University Control Over Revenue. As Of 2013, No Renovation Plans Have Been Formally Announced.
Memorial Coliseum Was Commissioned In 1921 As A Memorial To The Veterans Of World War I. The City Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
In February 2013, Dr. Chris Hill Announced Plans To Renovate Rice-eccles Stadium. The Renovation Will Add 10,000 Seats To The Stadium And Enclose The South End Zone.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. It Is Named After Robert Rice, A Health Club Pioneer From The State Of Utah Who Funded The Original Renovation Project, And Spencer Eccles, A University Of Utah Alumnus Who Donated $10 Million Toward The Major Renovation Project.
A Student Fund Drive, In Which Students And Businessmen Sold Plaques At $50 And $100 Levels, Provided The Capital Necessary To Get The Construction Project Off The Ground.

In The Middle Of A Three-year Renovation Project, Ad Scott Woodward Announced In Early 2013 That The Project Was On Time And On Budget. The Goal Is Still To Finish The Renovations Before The 2013 Season With No Public Event Scheduled Until Uw Opens Their Season Against Boise State On August 31. In Addition, The Football Operations Facilities Has Been Finalized At 80,000 Square Feet.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium But Is In The Market For A Sponsor To Collect Revenue For The Stadium Renovations.

Construction Continued In Early 2013 On The New Football Operations Building. Once The Building Is Complete, Construction Will Move To The Football Stadium. This Phase Will See Renovations To The Weight Rooms, Locker Rooms, And The Equipment Room. The School Also Announced That The Scoreboard Would Be Relocated To The East Side Of The Field.

The Stadium, Which Has Had Several Different Names Throughout Its History, Is Now Named After Clarence Martin, Former Governor Of Washington State Because His Son, Dan Martin, Gave The Team $250,000 In A Funding Project. Washington State Owns The Naming Rights.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Is Named After Two Alabama Greats. The First Is Paul W. Bryant, For His Winning Tradition As A Coach At Alabama. The Second Individual Is George Denny, Former University Of Alabama President.
The Stadium Was Financed Under President Rooseveltâ€™s New Deal.

In November 2012, The School Announced That They Had Commissioned A Study Regarding The Expansion Of The North End Zone Seating Area. An Additional Concourse Behind The New Seating Is Also Planned. Early Estimates Have The Renovation Project Between $78 And $95 Million In Costs.

The Stadium Is Named After The Donald Reynolds Foundation, Which Donated $20 Million For The 2001 Renovation That Added Roughly 20,000 Seats To The Stadium. The University Still Owns The Naming Rights.

The Stadium Is Named For James Ralph "shug" Jordan, Auburn's Winningest Football Coach, And Clifford Leroy Hare, A Member Of Auburn's First Football Team, President Of The Old Southern Conference, And Longtime Chairman Of Auburn's Faculty Athletic Committee. Legendary Coach Pat Dye Has Also Had His Name Forever Attached To Jordan-hare Stadium, As The Turf Officially Became Known As Pat Dye Field At Jordan-hare Stadium Prior To The 2005 Iron Bowl. Dye, Who Served As Head Coach And Athletics Director At Auburn From 1981-92 And Was Inducted Into The College Football Hall Of Fame In December 2005, Led Auburn To A 99-39-4 Record And Four Sec Championships In His Twelve Seasons.

The University Committee Took Out $118,000 In Personal Loans To Cover The Costs Of The Original Building During The Great Depression. Initially They Had Hoped For All Public Funding, But The Funds Were Not Provided Because The Public Felt That A Stadium Was Unnecessary At That Time.
Upgrades To West Concourse Were Completed In Late 2012. The Concourse And Concession Areas Were Widened, And New Concession Areas Were Set Up To Provide For More Food Options.
The Stadium Was Renamed In 1930 In Honor Of Citrus Tycoon Ben Hill Griffin, Jr., An Alumnus And Major Benefactor Of The University And Its Sports Programs.

Dr. Steadman Vincent Sanford Had An Idea To Have Members Of The Athletic Association Sign Notes Guaranteeing A Bank Loan To Fund The Stadium Construction. The Guarantors Would Be Granted Lifetime Seats. The Response Was Overwhelming, And In 1928 A Loan Of $150,000 Supported By Fans And Alumni Allowed Construction To Begin On A Stadium.

In May 2013, The University Approved $2.18 Million In Renovations To Sanford Stadium. Previously, The Outgoing University President Michael Adams Stated That If Renovations Should Take Place In The Future, It Should Only Be Done To The East Grandstands. These Remarks Are Notable Because The West End Is Also Quite Open. The Former President Noted That The West Side Should Not Be Enclosed, As The View Into Campus Is A Powerful Statement About The University.
Georgia Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Is Named After The Late Dr. Steadman Vincent Sanford, Former President Of The University And Chancellor Of The University System Of Georgia.
The Facility Was Made Possible Thanks To A $12 Million Donation By The Construction Firm Of Huber, Hunt, And Nichols.

Kentucky Governor Steve Beshear Signed Into Law A Bill Approving Building Upgrades At State Universities In Early 2013. Included In The Bill Is An Earmarked $110 Million For Renovation To Commonwealth Stadium. There Are Still No Concrete Plans For The Future Renovations.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium, Which Is Named For The Commonwealth Of Kentucky.

In September 2012, Lsu Replaced Lights On The Outside FaÃ§ade To Match The Scoreboard That Was Replaced In 2009. Instead Of White Lights, The Lights Alternate Between Purple And Gold (which Happen To Be The Teams Official Colors). Also In 2012, Plans For An Expansion To Tiger Stadium Continued As A State-financing Panel Approved The Addition Of New Seats To Tiger Stadium.
Lsu Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Is Named After The Team Nickname.
Davis Wade Stadium At Scott Field
100% University Financed Through Student, Faculty, And Donor Gifts.

In 2012, Missouri Announced Renovations To Faurot Field. The Plan Is To Add 6,000 Seats And Renovate The Press Box. Future Plans Call For The Addition Of An Upper Bowl, And An Additional 5,000 Seats. Construction Began In January Of 2013 And Is Expected To Take Eighteen Months To Complete.
The University Of Missouri Owns The Naming Rights And The Playing Field Is Named After Legendary Coach Don Faurot.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. When The Stadium Opened, It Was Named For Judge William Hemingway, A Professor Of Law And Chairman Of The Universityâ€™s Committee On Athletics. On October 12, 1982, Legendary Ole Miss Coach Johnny Vaughtâ€™s Name Was Added To The Stadium.
The Stadium Was Completely Funded Under President Rooseveltâ€™s New Deal.
After Finishing A Major Renovation To Increase Seating In 2012, Usc Also Replaced The Video Board. The $6.5 Million Video Board Was Installed In September 2012.

During The 1971 Stadium Expansion, A Significant Gift From The Estate Of Mrs. Martha Williams-brice Helped Increase The Capacity Of The Stadium From 43,000 To More Than 54,000. The Name Was Officially Changed From Carolina Stadium To Williams-brice Stadium During A Dedication Ceremony Before The September 9, 1972, Home Opener Against Virginia.
The Funding For The Stadium Was Provided By The State Of Tennessee.

The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium And It Is Named For General Robert R. Neyland, The Man Most Responsible For The Growth And Development Of Tennesseeâ€™s Proud Football Tradition. Neyland Served As Head Coach From 1926 To 1952, With Two Interruptions For Military Service.

In 2013, The Universityâ€™s Board Of Regents Approved A $450 Million Renovation Plan To Improve Kyle Field And Make It The Largest Capacity Stadium In The Sec, Seating Over 102,000. The Renovations Will Be Completed In Two Phases Beginning In November Of 2013 And 2014, Respectively, And Is Scheduled To Be Completed Before The 2015 Season Begins. The Renovations Will Not Displace The Aggies From Kyle Field During Construction.
Texas A&m Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium. The Stadium Was Named After Edwin James Kyle, Who Served As A Dean And Athletic Council President.

In Early 2013, The Athletics Department Surveyed Fans To Gauge The Interest Of Stadium Renovations. The Survey Asked The Fans To â€œput A Price On Footballâ€ù In Order To Determine What Fans Care Most About In Their Stadium. This Survey Is The First Step In Seeking Massive Renovations Of Vanderbilt Stadium.
Vanderbilt Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
The Original Cost Of The Stadium Was $2.5 Million, $1.4 Million Of Which Was Raised By Friends And Alumni. The State Provided The Rest Of The Money.

In September 2012, Asu Officials Announced A $22 Million Renovation Project To The North End Zone. The Project Consists Of Building A New State-of-the-art Football Operations Facility. New Locker Rooms And A Training Field Will Be Located Inside The Building.
In September 2012, Asu Announced A $5 Million Naming-rights Donation From Liberty Bank.

In May 2013, Ul Officially Announced The $115 Million Master Plan For The Program-wide Renovations And Expansion Of Their Athletics Facilities, Including Cajun Field . The Plans Call For Additional Seating And Luxury Boxes. In Addition, The Plan Is To Leave An Area South Of The Field Open For Green Space.
The University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium, Which Is Named After The School Nickname.
Malone Stadium Is Named For James Malone, The Winningest Coach In School History.
100% Privately Financed By A Local Banker Who Wanted To Honor His Mentor, Ernest F. Ladd.

Jim Wacker Field At Bobcat Stadium
Texas State University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium.
100% University Financed Through Donations And Gifts

Plans To Renovate Veterans Memorial Stadium Were Announced In 2012. The Proposed Expansion Will Include Football Locker Rooms, A Weight Room, Meeting Rooms, Ten To Fourteen Suites, Administrative Offices, Video And Technological Areas, A Recruiting Lounge, And An Academic Center.
Troy University Owns The Naming Rights To The Stadium, Which Reverted To Its Original Name When The Naming Rights Deal With Movie Gallery Ceased.

On July 19, 2007, Wku Reported That Houchens Industries, A Long-time Corporate Support Of Wku, Made A $5 Million Commitment To The Expansion And Renovation Project For The Football Stadium; The University Renamed The Stadium.

In June 2012, The Bcs Committee Unveiled A New Postseason Format. The Committee Announced A New, Four-team, Seeded Playoff. The Championship Game Will Be Managed By The Conferences And Will Not Be A Bowl Game. A Selection Committee Will Rank Teams To Play In The Playoffs. All Teams Will Be Given Equal Opportunity To Participate. There Will Not Be An Automatic Qualification Designation. When Deciding Which Teams Will Participate In The Playoff Games, The Committee Will Consider Factors Such As Strength Of Schedule, Win-loss Record, And Whether A Team Is A Conference Champion, Among Others. The New Format Will Being In The 2014â€“15 Season And Will Cover A Twelve-year Term Through The 2025â€“26 Season.

Under The New Format, The National Championship Game Will Rotate Between Six Locations. The First Host Will Be The Cotton Bowl Played At Cowboys Stadium In Arlington, Texas. Future Hosts Include The Chick-fil-a Bowl, The Fiesta Bowl, The Orange Bowl, And The Sugar Bowl.
The State Of Georgia Owns The Naming Rights To The Georgia Dome.
$325 Million Finaced By The Public, $150 Million Financed By The Nfl, And $525 Million Financed By The Dallas Cowboys.

The Nflâ€™s Arizona Cardinals Contributed $147 Million, The Arizona Sports And Tourism Authority Contributed More Than $298 Million, And The City Of Glendale, Arizona Contributed $9.5 Million.

The University Of Phoenix Acquired The Naming Rights To The Stadium In 2006. The Deal Is Worth $154.5 Million Over Twenty Years And Is Set To Expire In 2027.
90% Privately Funded With Money Generated By Leasing Luxury Boxes And Clubhouse Seats. The Remaining 10% Came From The State Of Florida.

The Orange Bowl Is Part Of The Bcs National Championship Game Rotation. It Hosted The Bcs National Championship Game In 2013. In March 2013, The Florida State Government Approved A Bill That Will Provide A $3 Million Per Year Tax Rebate And County Wide One-cent Tax Increase In Order To Help Fund Renovation Projects At Sun Life Stadium. The Upgrades Are Expected To Include The Addition Of A Canopy Over The Stadium, Increased Seating, And The Addition Of New Video Board Around The Stadium. In May 2013, The Expected Renovations Were Halted By The Florida State Government By Rejecting A Bill That Included A Bid For Public Financing.

The Rose Bowl Is Part Of The Bcs National Championship Rotation. The Rose Bowl Will Host The Bcs National Championship In 2014. Currently, The Rose Bowl Is Undergoing $180 Million In Renovations. As Of February 2013, The Project Was Still Focusing On Completing The Press Box And Pavilion Areas. In Addition, Foundations And Underground Utilities Have Been Added To The West Side Restrooms.

Mercedes-benz Obtained The Naming Rights For The Superdome In A Ten-year Deal That Is Expected To Expire In 2020. Terms Of The Deal Have Not Been Released.
